facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 43 of 1954 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 43 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal under Article 132(1) of the Constitution from Judgment and Order dated 22nd November 1952 of Judicial Commissioners Court, Ajmer, in Misc. Petition No. 226 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under Article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd November 1952 of the Judicial Commissioners Court, Ajmer, in Misc. Petition No. 226 of 1952.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 3, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. December 3. The judgment of Mehr Chand Mahajan C.J., Mukherjea, Vivian Bose, Bhagwati and Venkatarama Ayyar JJ. was delivered by Bose J.

facts.text: Appellant is the Istimrardar of Kharwa.

anchor.surface_text: BOSE J.-The appellant is the Istimrardar of Kharwa. According to him, be has held a cattle fair on his estate every year for some twenty years.

facts.text: Appellant held a cattle fair on his estate every year for some twenty years.

anchor.surface_text: According to him, be has held a cattle fair on his estate every year for some twenty years. On 8-1-1951 the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer framed certain rules for the regulation of cattle and other fairs in the State of Ajmer.

facts.text: Chief Commissioner of Ajmer framed rules on 8-1-1951 for regulation of cattle and other fairs under sections 40 and 41 of Ajmer Laws Regulation of 1877.

anchor.surface_text: On 8-1-1951 the Chief Commissioner of Ajmer framed certain rules for the regulation of cattle and other fairs in the State of Ajmer. He purported to do this under sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation of 1877  Reg. III of 1877 .

facts.text: One of the rules required persons desiring to hold fairs to obtain a permit from the District Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: One of the rules required that persons desiring to hold fairs should obtain a permit from the District Magistrate.

facts.text: Appellant applied for a permit to hold the fair.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly the appellant applied for a permit. This was refused on the ground that numbermore permits were to be issued to private individuals.

facts.text: Permit refused to appellant on ground that no more permits to be issued to private individuals.

anchor.surface_text: This was refused on the ground that numbermore permits were to be issued to private individuals. The appellant thereupon applied under article 226 of the Constitution to the Judicial 1067 Commissioners Court at Ajmer

facts.text: Appellant applied under Article 226 to Judicial Commissioners Court at Ajmer for writ directing authorities to permit holding the fair.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon applied under article 226 of the Constitution to the Judicial 1067 Commissioners Court at Ajmer for the issue of a writ directing the authorities companycerned to permit the appellant to hold his fair as usual.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner refused to issue the writ.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner refused to issue the writ but granted leave to appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner granted leave to appeal under Article 132(1).

anchor.surface_text: but granted leave to appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution in the following terms I am of opinion that the question whether the regulation and the bye-laws

facts.text: It is admitted that the land on which the fair is normally held belongs to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the land on which the fair is numbermally held belongs to the appellant. That being so, he has a fundamental right under article 19 1  f

facts.text: Appellant applied for permit on 9-7-1952.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellant applied for a permit on 9-7-1952  the District Magistrate replied It has been decided

facts.text: District Magistrate refused permit stating permits issued only to local bodies and not to private individuals.

anchor.surface_text: the District Magistrate replied It has been decided that as a matter of policy permits to hold fairs will be issued only to local bodies and number to private individuals.

facts.text: District Magistrate's order dated 18-9-1952 refusing permit.

anchor.surface_text: we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952. But we make numberorder about companyts

facts.text: Rules require District Magistrate to satisfy himself before issuing permit that applicant can establish proper system of conservancy, sanitation and watch and ward.

anchor.surface_text: satisfy himself, before issuing any permit, that the applicant is in a position to establish a proper system of companyservancy, sanitation and watch and ward at the fair.

facts.text: Fourth sub-rule of Rule I empowers District Magistrate to revoke permit without reasons or notice.

anchor.surface_text: The fourth sub-rule empowers the District Magistrate to revoke any such permit without assigning any reasons or giving any previous numberice.

facts.text: Supreme Court declared sub-rules of Rule I ultra vires the Regulation.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the rules travel beyond the Regu- 1069 lation in at least two respects. ... Therefore, in effect, the rules empower the District Magistrate

facts.text: Supreme Court quashed District Magistrate's order dated 18-9-1952.

anchor.surface_text: we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952. But we make numberorder about companyts because the point

facts.text: Appeal allowed and order of Judicial Commissioner set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void

facts.text: District Magistrate's order dated 18th September 1952 declining permit on ground permits only to local bodies.

issues.text: Whether the rules framed by the Chief Commissioner under sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation, 1877 are ultra vires those provisions

anchor.surface_text: Section 41 provides for penalties in the following terms The Chief Commissioner may, in making any rule under this Regulation, attach to the breach

issues.text: Whether the rules delegate to the District Magistrate the power to determine and impose a system of conservancy, sanitation and watch and ward, which is beyond the Chief Commissioner's authority under the Regulation

anchor.surface_text: the rules travel beyond the Regu- 1069 lation in at least two respects. The Regulation empowers the Chief Commissioner to make rules for the establishment of a system of companyservancy and sanitation.

issues.text: Whether the rules constitute a proper system of conservancy, sanitation and watch and ward under section 40 or merely establish ad hoc control through permits by the District Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: I am of opinion that the question whether the regulation and the bye-laws framed thereunder amount to a reasonable restriction on the appellants fundamental right to hold a cattle fair in his own land involves a substantial question of law

arguments.claim: he has a fundamental right under article 19 1 f which can only be restricted in the manner permitted by sub-clause 5 . The holding of an annual fair is an occupation or business within the meaning of article 19 1 g

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that the land on which the fair is normally held belongs to the appellant. That being so, he has a fundamental right under article 19 1 f which can only be restricted in the manner permitted by sub-clause 5 .

arguments.claim: the rules travel beyond the Regulation because they delegate to the District Magistrate the power to determine what a proper system of conservancy etc is

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the rules travel beyond the Regu- 1069 lation in at least two respects. The Regulation empowers the Chief Commissioner to make rules for the establishment of a system of conservancy and sanitation.

arguments.claim: the fourth sub-rule empowers the District Magistrate to revoke permit without reasons or notice conferring absolute arbitrary power which is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: Further, under the fourth sub-rule of Rule I the District Magistrate is empowered to revoke a permit granted without assigning any reasons or giving any previous notice. This absolute and arbitrary power uncontrolled by any discretion is also ultra vires.

arguments.claim: The Regulation assumes the right of persons to hold fairs and requires due regard for conservancy etc via rules by Chief Commissioner; cannot arbitrarily prohibit via District Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: The Regulation assumes the right of persons to hold fairs, and all it requires is that those who do so should have due regard for the requirements of conservancy and sanitation and in order that they may know just what these requirements are,

arguments.claim: The matter is covered by the decision of this Court in Tahir Hussain v. District Board, Muzafarnagar

anchor.surface_text: The matter is covered by the decision of this Court in Tahir Hussain v. District Board, Muzafarnagar 1 . The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside.

arguments.claim: rules do not authorise District Magistrate to reject permit application on ground of policy to issue only to local bodies

anchor.surface_text: The rules under which he is to grant or refuse permits in this behalf only authorise him to satisfy himself that the applicant is in a position to establish a proper system of conservancy, sanitation and watch and ward at the fair

arguments.claim: the rules themselves are not within the ambit of the rule-making power under sections 40 and 41 as they constitute ad hoc control not a proper system of conservancy etc

anchor.surface_text: These rules purport to have been framed in exercise of the powers conferred by sections 40 and 41 of the Ajmer Laws Regulation, 1877. Section 40 authorises the framing of the rules for the maintenance of watch and ward and the establishment of a proper system

holdings.text: the rules travel beyond the Regulation in at least two respects

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the rules travel beyond the Regu- 1069 lation in at least two respects. The Regulation empowers the Chief Commissioner to make rules for the establishment of a system of companyservancy and sanitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Regulation authorizes Chief Commissioner to establish system of conservancy by rules, not delegate determination to District Magistrate; also confers no arbitrary revocation power

holdings.text: the action of the Chief Commissioner in delegating this authority to the District Magistrate is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: What he has done is to leave it to the District Magistrate to see that persons desiring to hold a fair are in a position to establish a proper system of companyservancy, etc. But who, according to this, is to determine what a proper system is obviously the District Magistrate. Therefore, in effect, the rules empower the District Magistrate to make his own system and see that it is observed. But the Regulation companyfers this power on the Chief Commissioner and number on the District Magistrate, therefore the action of the Chief Commissioner in delegating this authority to the District Magistrate is ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Chief Commissioner must incorporate system in rules for all to know and comply; cannot leave determination to DM as that delegates rule-making power not conferred by Regulation

holdings.text: This absolute and arbitrary power uncontrolled by any discretion is also ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: Further, under the fourth sub-rule of Rule I the District Magistrate is empowered to revoke a permit granted without assigning any reasons or giving any previous numberice. This absolute and arbitrary power uncontrolled by any discretion is also ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fourth sub-rule allows revocation without reasons or notice, conferring uncontrolled arbitrary power not authorized by Regulation

holdings.text: As these sub-rules of Rule I are ultra vires, the District Magistrates order, which in effect prohibits the holding of the fair, is also bad

anchor.surface_text: The Regulation assumes the right of persons to hold fairs, and all it requires is that those who do so should have due regard for the requirements -of companyservancy and sanitation and in order that they may know just what these requirements are, the Chief Commissioner  number some lesser authority  is given the power to draw up a set of rules stating what is necessary. ... As these sub-rules of Rule I are ultra vires, the District Magistrates order, which in effect prohibits the holding of the fair, is also bad for, without the aid of these rules or of some other law validly

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-rules invalid as exceed Regulation; DM order relies on them without other valid authority, hence invalid

holdings.text: The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952

anchor.surface_text: The matter is companyered by the decision of this Court in Tahir Hussain v. District Board, Muzafarnagar 1 . The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules void per above analysis; follows precedent in Tahir Hussain; quashes DM order as consequence

holdings.text: The order of the District Magistrate dated the 18th September, 1952, declining to grant a permit to hold the cattle fair on the ground that it has been decided to issue permits only to local bodies and not to private individuals is bad for two reasons

anchor.surface_text: JAGANNADHADAS J.-The order of the District Magistrate dated the 18th September, 1952, declining to grant a permit to hold the cattle fair on the ground that it has been decided

holdings.reasoning_summary: DM refusal on unauthorized policy ground; rules themselves invalid

holdings.text: The rules under which he is to grant or refuse permits in this behalf only authorise him to satisfy himself that the applicant is in a position to establish a proper system of companyservancy, sanitation and watch and ward at the fair

anchor.surface_text: The rules under which he is to grant or refuse permits in this behalf only authorise him to satisfy himself that the applicant is in a position to establish a proper system of companyservancy, sanitation and watch and ward at the fair and also to impose such terms and companyditions as he may deem fit. But they do number authorise him to reject an application on the ground on which he has done.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules limit DM discretion to checking applicant's conservancy capability and imposing terms; no authority for policy-based refusal to private individuals

holdings.text: The rules themselves under which the permit has been asked for and with reference to which the District Magistrate declined to grant the permit are number within the ambit of the rule-making power

anchor.surface_text: But they do number authorise him to reject an application on the ground on which he has done. The rules themselves under which the permit has been asked for and with reference to which the District Magistrate declined to grant the permit are number within the ambit of the rule-making power.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules create ad hoc permit control by DM, not a 'proper system' of conservancy etc. as required by s.40

holdings.text: These cannot be said to be rules which in themselves companystitute a system of companyservancy, sanitation and watch and ward

anchor.surface_text: The net effect of these rules is merely to establish a system of ad hoc companytrol by the District Magistrate through the issue of a permit and by the vesting of other powers in him under the rules. These cannot be said to be rules which in themselves companystitute a system of companyservancy, sanitation and watch and ward. Thus the result that is brought about is number within the intend- ment of the section which authorises the making of the rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules effect ad hoc control via permits, not establishment of proper system under s.40; exceeds legislative intent

holdings.text: it is number necessary to express any opinion as to whether the impugned order infringes also the appellants fundamental rights under article 19

anchor.surface_text: The impugned order of the District Magistrate being bad on both the above grounds, this is enough to dispose of the appeal and it is number necessary to express any opinion as to whether the impugned order infringes also the appellants fundamental rights under article 19.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Decision rests on statutory invalidity; no need to reach constitutional Art.19 question

anchor.surface_text: What he has done is to leave it to the District Magistrate to see that persons desiring to hold a fair are in a position to establish a proper system of companyservancy, etc. But who, according to this, is to determine what a proper system is obviously the District Magistrate. Therefore, in effect, the rules empower the District Magistrate to make his own system and see that it is observed. But the Regulation companyfers this power on the Chief Commissioner and number on the District Magistrate, therefore the action of the Chief Commissioner in delegating this authority to the District Magistrate is ultra vires.

The appeal is allowed and the order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. We declare that the rules are void to the extent indicated above and we quash the order of the District Magistrate dated 18-9-1952. But we make numberorder about companyts because the point on which we have proceeded was number

anchor.surface_text: The net effect of these rules is merely to establish a system of ad hoc companytrol by the District Magistrate through the issue of a permit and by the vesting of other powers in him under the rules. These cannot be said to be rules which in themselves companystitute a system of companyservancy, sanitation and watch and ward. Thus the result that is brought about is number within the intend- ment of the section which authorises the making of the rules.
